summary.p: Complains bitterly that he traveled to Zofingen in vain and has since heard nothing from Bullinger. A replacement must be found for the sick Franz [Kolb].

div.p: Greetings. I was not worthy for any of your people from Zofingen to meet me, as I had gone there at great risk to my health for the sake of renewing our friendship, and since that time, I have not been worthy to receive even a single letter from you. If I knew this was due to my fault, it would certainly cause me the greatest pain, but since I am well aware of my conscience regarding both of you, I am forced to bear both the absence and the silence indifferently and to endure my labors in my corner.

Franz can no longer perform his duties due to a large goiter, so we will need another assistant. For this reason, when your advice was needed, I could neither share my own nor request yours, unless it entirely slipped my mind, which, due to the neglected opportunity, I could not fulfill my wishes towards you especially.
Bern, on the very day of Ascension, 1535.
To Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest brother.
